title: Will flying cars ever happen? - Quora

response.answer_text: For flying cars to be possible, you have to solve the following problems: Air traffic control. It’s bad enough with just relatively few aircraft, can you imagine if everyone had a flying machine? You’d need an ATC system that’s completely automated and run exclusively by computers (not humans) to handle it, which leads me onto my next point -Driving licenses. The standards of a pilot license are much, much higher than for a driving license. Many car drivers barely know how an engine works, whereas a pilot is examined on most of the technical aspects of aircraft before they ever get to fly one. Therefore, the majority of people, while they are adequate drivers, would be poor pilots. You would need to have the car be self-flying (again, more fully computerised systems) for it to be accessible to the average driver. Your average driver is not going to enjoy sitting for dozens of exams and having to pass a more stringent medical every few years to get their pilot’s license. Once you have self-driving/flying cars, you just need to solve problem #3:Equipment. Again, the standards for cars are much more relaxed than they are for aircraft, because naturally if something fails on your car you can usually escape with minimal injuries, but on an aircraft even something as minor as a shorted electrical connector can turn into an emergency. That’s why, on commercial aircraft, maintenance has to be done by qualified staff at tightly-regulated facilities with impeccable documentation. For small aircraft, under certain conditions, it is possible for the owner/pilot to do some of the work himself, but remember this is someone who passed his pilot’s license and thus has a certain level of technical know-how and, hopefully, the right attitude of not taking-on tasks that are beyond their capability. Now, imagine you have a flying car in the hands of an average driver. What’s to stop them from making a modification on their car that causes it to fall out of the sky? Even with regular cars, where we have all sorts of rules, like exhaust loudness limits, and emissions controls, and speed limiters, people still break the law every day. Having a flying car just compounds the problem. Adding a roof rack to a normal car just adds a bit of drag; doing the same on a flying car could change the aerodynamics enough to make it dangerous. Putting a big weight in the boot of a normal car is no big deal (at worst the suspension might bottom-out). Doing the same in a flying car might move the center of gravity so far backwards that it becomes impossible to recover from a stall, causing it to plummet to the ground. So flying cars would need security measures to keep them from being tampered with, and systems to detect such tampering and refuse to fly until it’s been rectified. You also need foolproofing to counteract situations like the overloading-the-boot one I just mentioned. Problem is, no matter how good your foolproofing system gets, they always build a better fool! ;)So perhaps in light of this, flying cars would best be implemented as “flying taxis”, where you don’t own or drive them, but rather call them using an app like you do with uber, and ride them to your destination. That way, the company operating the cars would take care of all the maintenance and other tricky issues, and the high cost of buying one is borne by them (and reflected in a slightly higher ticket price), rather than you having to cough up several tens of thousands of extra dollars over the cost of a regular one to buy one.

There are several of them now and have been for decades. The main problems aren’t technological, as you might think, but rather human-based. The most promising flying cars now are more like roadable airplanes and they don’t do particularly well in traffic and don’t hover.   Others kind of give up on the whole wheeled vehicle thing and try to be the equivalent of an automobile but only useful in the air.   So there’s a lot of experimentation going on and we have several kinds of flying cars right now. But there are reasons we don’t see them anywhere, even though people have been dreaming about them for 100 years. Some of the reasons can be addressed but others can’t. Lifting something into the air takes enormous amounts of energy, especially if it has no wings and is expected to hover. This would make a flying car fantastically expensive to operate. Making them lighter would help.A flying vehicle is complex to operate and poses many safety risks. People need many hours of special training to do it and there are only a few places where they’re allowed to land and take off, so they’re not convenient to use. Software might help with this and basically fly the thing for you and allow it to land on skyscraper rooftops like a helicopter.The last issue can’t be resolved. A flying car is as LOUD AS HELL. The noise, dust, wind and spectacle will make them unwelcome in any neighborhood or urban area. No one will want a flying car anywhere near them, unless they are in it. No cities would ever approve them for use in residential areas. No one ever thinks about this, but they will when they are near one landing or taking off.The most promising design, I think, is something like this, a flying jitney (minibus) that would be used able to land and take off in far more places than an airplane. A dozen people or so would crowd into it and it could go from skyscraper to skyscraper in or between crowded cities, quickly picking up and dropping off passengers. Many paying passengers could offset the cost and no one lives on skyscraper roofs anyway, so it wouldn’t bother people. Software could safely operate it.

Yes, but... 1) They will be really expensive - over $300,000 in 2015 US Dollars, maybe $800,000. 2) You will probably need to have a private pilot's license and more than 200 hours before the you can buy one.  There will be extensive type training, almost as much as float plane / sea plane training.  The manufacturers will not want the aircraft to get a bad reputation by selling to low-time or risky pilots.  I would not be surprised if the manufacturer requires 500 hours and an instrument rating. 3) There will be restrictions on where they can be used.  While places like Alaska and very rural parts of Western States like Nevada, Utah, Idaho, etc.Will be favorable, and MIGHT even allow take off from selected rural roads, the rest of the nation will be much more restrictive.Some of those states did have provisions for some people to land and take off from public roads years ago. See Steve's answer here : Steve Blumenkranz's answer to Will flying cars ever happen?They aren't going to flying in Connecticut, but no one will care much if youcrash in some potato field in Idaho. 4) It is very likely that "flying cars" / "roadable aircraft" will not be able to handle adverse weather as well as conventional aircraft.   So this will limit where and when these vehicles can be used.  Late afternoon turbulence may mean no flying.  Same with snow or icing conditions. 5)  The range and speed will tend to be limited, compared to conventional aircraft.  A Cessna 172 will do 140 mph and 600+ miles. Expect something like 110-125 mph and as little as 250 -300 miles, while using more fuel. 6)  The NHTSA has been exempting "flying cars" / "roadable aircraft" from the crash safety regulations, to help keep the weight down. 7)  And no, there won't be an automated self-flying car for a long time, maybe around 40 years.  And there will still need to be a competent pilot in command. Terrafugia Transition

Flying cars suffer from multiple problems that no one has yet solved. 1 Need a pilot’s license. Going rate is typically $10,000. And that only covers flying single engine aircraft in good weather. Add Instrument rating (bad weather) and the cost goes to like $20,000. People seem to think that you buy a flying car, and anyone with a drivers license can fly it. Nope. Not gonna happen. 2 Weight. Aircraft MUST be light to fly. Cars need to be strong to pass mandatory crash tests. Those requirements are contradictory. A Cessna 172, about the smallest 4-passenger aircraft, weighs 1,691 pounds empty. By comparison, a Toyota Corolla, a small 4-passenger car, weighs 2,870 pounds. And the Corolla has no wings, no rudder, no horizontal stabilizer, etc. 3 If you think auto insurance is expensive now, wait until a flying car is made and the first one gets into a fender bender. Since ONLY FAA certified mechanics are allowed to work on aircraft, the price of a ‘fender bender’ will be HUGE, think 4-8 TIMES the current rate. What will that do to the cost of insurance, for everyone! 4 Confusion. Two complete sets of controls, gauges, dials, indicators, etc. are needed. In addition, all the exterior aircraft lights must be there, as well as the auto exterior lights. More complications and more weight. Note that LCD panels help here for instrument panels. 5 Costs. Even inexpensive aircraft are expensive, and trying to make one that will be both a car AND a aircraft will require fancy, expensive materials, like carbon fiber, to help make #2 above work. In essence, it would cost more than Rolls-Royce. Can YOU afford a brand new Rolls-Royce? If not, then you cannot afford a flying car. 6 More costs. All maintenance, beyond an oil change or changing a light bulb, must, by law, be performed by an FAA licensed mechanic. Parts must come from FAA certified vendors. All this add up to higher and higher costs, many times the cost of auto maintenance. And in an aircraft, it must be done, by law, and the aircraft must be inspected, by law, including detailed paperwork, annually. 7. Airports. Unless the flying car is a helicopter, it needs runways at both ends of the flight. That takes space, which is costly, meaning landing fees will be high. Do YOU own a house on a runway? If not, where are you going to take off? And airports charge for every landing you make-it’s their prime source of income. Think of paying a tax every time you drive. 8. Air traffic control. ATC is difficult now, then think about adding hundreds of small aircraft to the mix, all wanting to go to just a few destinations. Nightmare-collisions all over the skies! There is a simple solution. 1 Drive in your car to the airport. 2 Get in you existing aircraft, and fly to your destination 3 After landing, rent a car. Which sounds cheaper and easier?

In engineering terms a lot of things are possible. However, to make a flying car will involve the mixing of two differing technological requirements. The legal and necessary requirements for road vehicles involve crash resistance in various types if impact scenarios. The current ones in most countries mean that the structure needed is very robust and hence quite heavy. A flight vehicle must be light and well-powered in order to get off the ground. These are really quite conflicting, so a flying car will be the worst of both technologies, inefficient and expensive to operate. That is without the requirements for the pilot training of the ‘drivers’ who will need pilot’s licences with night and instrument ratings. The flight vehicles will be subject to maintenance and inspections as for all light aeroplanes and there is no way such inspection regimes will be reduced as the safety of those not only in the air, but on the ground will need to be considered. Then there is the market price of the product to be considered. The sales volumes would be low in view of the requirements and the purchase price would be astronomical compared to a top-end luxury car. How convenient would it then be to use a ‘flying car’. It would be noisy to take off and land, so it would need to be flown from airfields or approved sites only. For journeys in or near controlled airspace a flight plane would need to be filed for each flying journey. That is not very convenient. The ability of the pilots of these vehicles to safely navigate the skies, even with a high degree of computer control is also a factor. There would be accidents and crashes from the flight element of journeys and restrictions would be demanded by citizens after a few fatal crashes. So yes, it is possible in time, but not particularly feasible or practical. Such flight vehicles would be for the very few rich people who could afford the huge purchase, maintenance and inspection requirements. The move to cleaner, quieter and more fuel efficient will reduce the practicality of ‘flying cars’ still further.

Self-flying human carrying drones are coming to urban areas with pay-per-use trip costs lower than ground vehicles but reduced cargo capacity. Uber Elevate should be one service operating them. We’re already moving to non personally owned vehicles because parking is too expensive and time consuming in large cities. While those currently use human drivers, they’ll be automated as soon as technology allows because people are the most expensive part of services like Uber and Lyft. Self-flying vehicles are also coming because Ground traffic is already too congested.City planners are adding office space for thousands more people (like the 1070 foot Salesforce Tower in San Francisco with room for 7000+) without improving surface transportation capacity.Hundreds of thousands of dollars in capital costs are affordable when amortized over years of many users’ trips, not the twice-daily commutes plus errands of today’s personally owned cars costing tens of thousands.Trip costs will eventually beat ground vehicles because quantities of scale will bring down production costs and without waiting in traffic, flying vehicles will have a higher trip per hour rate. Uber published a white paper producing the same conclusion 18 months ago in October, 2016: https://www.uber.com/elevate.pdf Our analysis shows that in the long-term autonomous case, direct costs per vehicle mile will approach 50 cents per mile (equivalent to 35 cents per ground mile). We can expect that the price for a 45-mile pool VTOL, which would replace a 60-mile automobile trip, could approach as low as $21 for the 15 minute journey. I expect the first passenger operations before we have fully autonomous ground vehicles because fewer surprises are possible in open air than on the roads. Prototypes are already making manned flights  although I expect we’ll use vehicles like the tilt-wing A-cubed Vahana for acceptable efficiency and battery life. They’re aiming to start sales in 2020. Airbus' 'flying car' takes to the skies for the first time  Uber Elevate promo video:  Autonomous flying vehicles providing on-demand sub-20 minute commutes over the Diablo Mountains could have an interesting effect on San Francisco Bay Area real estate.

The type of flying car that exists today are planes that can be folded in ways that allow them to drive on roads. They are very expensive, inefficient, and they aren’t very good at being either planes or cars.   If you are talking about “blade runner” style flying cars, then we have several problems to work out before they can be practical. We need a massive upgrade in energy storage or propulsion technology. You need to have a significant range flying a vehicle that doesn’t generate much lift with the body. That takes a lot of power. Which means a lot of electric charge or fuel. You don’t want to run out of juice with this one.We need a massive upgrade with vehicle control systems. Right now, it’s difficult to learn how to pilot an aircraft, and that’s in a much emptier sky. Learning how to pilot in a city with buildings and other flying cars around is going to be incredibly difficult. I don’t expect that these will be automated systems for the most part.We need a massive upgrade in airspace control systems. When flying cars start becoming commonplace then there is going to need to be ways to ensure that they don’t become a threat to each other. Our current systems are not designed for urban environments and many small vehicles.We need a massive upgrade in terms of reliability. Aircraft require significant maintenance. This is because when there’s a problem, you can’t just pull to the side of the road. You risk falling out of the sky. This is a much more serious problem with non-lift bodies. A Cessna can glide without power. These designs cannot.Once we’ve solved these four huge technical issues, then we need to work on the regulatory issues to create a legal framework for these new vehicles.With all of these problems, it puts practical flying cars beyond the predictable future.

Some such vehicles are available now. To a degree, the long, long effort at flying cars is a waste of time because to be a good car, it wouldn’t be a good aircraft and to be a good aircraft, it wouldn’t be a good car. With the heavy development of drones with four or more propellers, is there hope for an electric drone/car? What would you do with the propellers between flights? With fixed wing, you have the problem of the engine and those long wings, which make for a very awkward car. More than likely, sometime in the next 10 to 50 years (probably sooner than later), you will be able to hop in an electric quadcopter and go on short trips without a pilot. I say this because a quadcopter is much less complicated, in the flying portion, than a traditional helicopter because it doesn’t need the highly complex gearing system necessary for helicopters. Quad drones literally fly themselves right now, the pilot on the ground simply directs them. I have a preliminary design for something I am calling an “air car” which would be a partially flying, guided system above the ground with no engine. No engine. There is no prototype at present and, frankly, I am not sure if my design will work, but that is what R&D is for, isn’t it? If it works, it would take you 200 to 300 miles in an hour to an hour and a half. The goal is to have a functional system by 2019 or, at the very minimum, a large scale, operating model. We need to explore all kinds of new alternatives. Railroads are essentially 19th century technology and mag-lev trains have proven very expensive, to say the least. With the need for long runways, aircraft become self defeating landing outside cities when the distance is less than 300 or 400 miles. (I can drive from my house in Maryland to the airport in Newark, just outside NYC, in about the same time span as flying, three hours, taking into account clearing security, the plane taxing and then meeting up with some sort of local transportation once there. In fact, if you bother to get a rental car, the total trip time would like be an hour longer than driving.) I am not a believer in the hyperloop hype. For one thing, it is another system that would be damned expensive to build. We need simpler, faster and overall better.

I’m certain flying cars will exist in the future. After all, they already existed many years ago.  From the Federal Aviation Administrations’ (FAA) viewpoint “Flying Cars” will undoubtedly be essentially treated as airplanes that can also drive on the road. The only thing that will likely govern the widespread adoption of flying cars is that: A Flying Car “Driver” will have to have a Pilots License, periodic medical examination, periodic flight reviews, etc. when the vehicle is operated in the Federal Airspace System. In other words, the “pilot” will have to operate under he same regulations and costs as “normal” pilots.When operating as an aircraft, it will be subject to the same airspace regulations that aircraft are. Which means that there are some places — notably congested airspace like Los Angeles, New York, San Francisco, etc. — that will require specific approval to fly within. That approval isn’t guaranteed.When transitioning from Flying Car to Airplane and visa versa, the vehicle will have to operate from an existing (or yet to be created) “Airport.”The “Flying Car” will be treated as an airplane and as such will be subject to very thorough “Annual Inspections” as well as at least a couple of other inspections.The acquisition costs of both the vehicle, pilots license, etc as outlined above will undoubtedly be the key criteria that governs how widespread the adoption of “Flying Cars” will be.Here is some additional information on the potential adoption of Flying Cars: Joe Shelton's answer to Will flying cars on Earth ever make sense?

Doubt it. There’s four major obstacles. One’s engineering. Either you are making a car or an aircraft. If you’re making an aircraft you need a bigger, fatter engine in there and lots of aerofoils and some means of controlling them. If you’re making a car you need a smaller engine and means of steering and control, as well as a gearbox and all the other paraphernalia. Where are you going to put it all and what will it weigh? Two is where you’re going to drive/take off/land. You could conceivably put it on a road with wings folded but you’d have a huge protuberance sticking up that may contravene height regulations and cause an enormous drag, and in high winds you’d be blowing over. You can’t get up to take-off speed on a normal road and as soon as you land you’ll be breaking the speed limit. Your local constabulary will be on your case constantly. Three is legal. Are you a driver or a pilot? Will you have to take both tests? What will your insurance be? Will you have to file a flight plan before you take to the skies? How will it be controlled whilst you’re in flight? Will you have to have take-off and landing permissions? What airspace can and cannot you use? Four is commercial. What will it cost in R&D and manufacturing and can the money be recouped with profit? How will we service them? Is there a big enough demand, and given the legal above, can the demand be reduced by restriction on persons qualified or suitability of intended location of use? It’s likely that these problems, especially the second, are going to be insurmountable. I doubt we’ll ever see a car made by a major manufacturer that can act as an aircraft or vice-versa, at least not as anything other than a concept.

For many years the concept of flying cars have been the dream of science fiction writers and readers. For many years the US Army and Marine Corps have “lusted” for a HMMWV-like vehicle that can drive with four troops and then “hop” over marshland and lakes and rivers. That “hop” could be (and most likely is) flying. However, when it comes to reality and for civilian use, one must make the “flying car” or more likely the “roadable airplane” Cost effectiveMeet all of the FAA/EASA regulations for an airplane as well as meeting all of the highway safety regulations of the various countries/regionsCurrently there are two “flying vehicles”: From the Netherlands: The world's first flying car you can buy is now taking ordersFrom Woburn, MA in the USA (and now financed by China): The Transition - TerrafugiaI say “vehicle”, because of this: I saw the announcement of the Dutch PAL V and it stated that it had met all of the requirements of the NHTSA for the USA and the various agencies in Europe. But I wondered, because the Terrafugia Transition had to get waivers from the FAA in order to meet all of the NHTSA requirements as a car. So, I did what any aerospace engineer would do, and I contacted the NHTSA and a very nice agent called me and we had a long discussion. Take a look at the Dutch PAL V. It only has three-wheels……. Therefore it is Not a car, but a Motorcycle. And as we all know, motorcycles in the USA do Not have seat belts nor air bags nor crash resistant bumpers, etc. Therefore, the PAL-V could meet the regulations as a motorcycle (you will need a motorcycle addition on your drivers license in most US states) and still remain below the weight limits for a FAA Light Sport Aircraft. Whereas the Transition, as a four wheel Car, had to meet the plethora of NHTSA regulations for safety which drove up the basic weight and therefore the FAA had to issue a waiver to allow the additional weight and the higher minimum landing speed and still be classified as a light sport aircraft. Neither will be inexpensive. Are they practical….. The owner will be the judge of that. There are sufficient numbers of people who will spend upwards of $300,000 or more to have one. Enjoy your flight and occasional drive. And may you Not get hit by a car or a grocery cart while parked in a parking lot…..

As a person who works in my state's Department of Motor vehicles... I can say with some experience that flying automobiles are a really stupid idea that seems much better in theory than it would be in reality. Most motorists have a difficult enough time mastering movement of their cars in two dimensions... add a third, altitude, or height above ground, and there would be absolute chaos. Drunk, driving is bad enough now... add flying cars to the mix, and you WILL have "drunk flying" in addition... and hitting the ground from any reasonable altitude is not a pleasant experience. Additionally, the skies are already filled with commercial jets, military aviation, pleasure flying with small planes, not to mention birds, and potentially, someday, airships. With all this, adding thousands of flying cars to the mix would create massive problems in control and collison avoidence. Imagine... if you will, a driver with his flying car accidentally hitting a large commercial jet, causing it to crash, killing hundreds of people, probably including himself! Flying cars have been a staple of science fiction stories for decades... but when you consider the many problems that would arise if you actually had such vehicles... it is quite clear that such an idea is really not a practical one... and should be left to science fiction novels and movies... where they can't hurt anyone. After all, if flying cars were really that good of an idea... they would have been in common use already!

I doubt it. There have been any number of attempts dating back longer than I have been alive. I recall being aware, in the early 1960s, of failed attempts dating from the 1950s. Just the other day a friend posted a video to Facebook of a report by a major news organization announcing the availability of the “first commercially available flying car” and that it was being shown at the Geneva Auto Show. The catch is that I have seen the same sort of announcement probably six times…at least once for every decade I have been alive. Every last one of them has been a technical or commercial failure…or both. This latest one is basically a gyrocopter with folding rotor blades and mast. It’s a two seat, three wheel vehicle that sells for $599,000 and, being a gyrocopter, it’s not going to be fast.  I will admit, it looks like a pretty cool machine but, for that amount of money I could buy a car and an airplane, both of which would perform better in the separate roles than this compromise vehicle, and I would have money left over. Because of how it works you’ll still need a pilot’s licence and you’ll have to operate it from an airport. It’s hard to say, just looking at photos, but I do wonder how well it meets modern crash standards for cars. The fundamental problem is that the term “flying car” is misleading. It’s a great name, in terms of marketing, but the reality is that every one of these projects is really an aircraft you can drive on the road, and that involves so many compromises that it’s not worth doing. Perhaps some day, but not yet.

There’s a lot of talk about flying cars. Many refer to self-driving flying cars, so as to remove the dangers of the human factor so brilliantly summarized by Jacque Scott in his answer. I want to add a few more things. A “flying vehicle” is a very different thing from a car. First of all lightness is paramount. So much that a flying vehicle is an exxtremely delicate thing. If you punch strong enough the sheet metal of the wing of a little airplane, your fist will go right through it. You may have noticed that above the wings of jet liners, there are areas marked with thick lines and the words: “don’t step beyond this line” this means that even the largest, sturdiest airplanes are built so lightly that in some parts they will not stand the weight of a person standing. For the same reasons, flying vehicles can’t have bumpers, rubber door protections or anti-crash cages. Not only they will never pass any crash test, but a person that cannot park properly may damage your flying vehicle so much that it won’t be able to fly. Secondly, flying requires that the vehicle is supported by something that generates lift. Either a wing, which requires a continuous, substantial airspeed, or a rotor. Both require mechanical energy. The rotor requires A LOT OF mechanical energy. Mechanical energy is generated by a motor. The motor requires some kind of energy that comes from a fuel or from batteries. Stop producing energy and the flying machine will fall to the ground, while your ordinary car will simply stop at the shoulder. This means two things: the first is that your motor can’t fail and you can’t run out of fuel. The second is that it will consume a lot more energy than a car, whose weight is simply supported by a solid surface. And since weight is paramount (see point #1) you will have to choose between range and payload. Sorry mother-in-law, you will travel without luggage or we won’t be able to load enough fuel to reach destination. Third: talks have it that flying cars will free us from congestion, because we will be able to occupy a three-dimensional space, instead of two dimensional roads. But sooner or later all flying vehicles will need to get back to the two-dimensional ground below them, possibly at designated points of landing. This means that a good share of this ideal three-dimensional space will be occupied by descent and ascend corridors. Moreover, the distance between one flying vehicle and the next, in the direction of travel, but also sideways, above and under,will be much greater than the diastance between cars on a road. The very current proposed rule-making by the FAA for managing drone traffic, aka Remote Id, is to put together a network where autonomous and piloted drones may be safely operated beyond VLOS-Visual Line of Sight and share the airspace with hundreds of other drones and piloted aircraft operating in an urban area, and also with commercial spaceports, where Elon Musk or Richard Branson is in your area. Many or most of the working delivery drones in the US, like ZipLine, and prototypes by Google Wing are operating with waivers under FAA Part 107 regulations for small drones, 55 pounds and less. They’re limited to 400 feet max altitude and have been granted limited waivers to operate autonomously, beyond VLOS, safely. The UPS early entries, carrying medical samples and supplies among fixed delivery points, are with waivers from FAA Part 135 for commercial aircraft up to 12,500 pounds and larger. They propose operating larger drones that can operate in the air traffic control system, above 500 feet and up to jet routes, along with general aviation and other air carriers. One of the sketches I’ve seen is a turbine-powered drone that can carry a pickup-truck load, a couple of pallets. I can sit at my desk and plan a mission with DroneDeploy or FlyLitchi right now and take a drone out to fly it. With today’s laws, I’ve got to keep my eye on the drone for the entire flight. After Remote Id is worked out, I can send my drone anywhere that’s not restricted airspace. Skydio 2, DJI enterprise and professional drones, Autel, and others are waiting for the tech and protocols to be decided, and they’ll build drones with the tech to fly from point-to-point. They’ve got charging boxes that pop up and launch a drone from a first-responder’s vehicle, or slide out from a construction manager’s trailer. All we’re missing is the standards. Currently we’re responding to the FAA’s proposed regulations: Press Release - U.S. Department of Transportation Issues Proposed Rule on Remote ID for Drones I’m entirely supportive of what they propose, but hope I can continue operating my drones within VLOS as I do now, and hope the RC community isn’t shut down. RC hobbyists and droners have been operating safely for lots of decades and I see no reason flight within VLOS should be obsolete. My DJI drones already broadcast everything I do to any authority with an AeroScop within range, and that’s fine with me. We’ve obviously got the tech to pick up a 5 pound package or half ton of cargo and take it from one place to another. A drone with a Pratt & Whitney or Rolls Royce turbine could easily be rigged to carry people. Google ‘passenger drones’ and check out the images. What’s missing for you ‘flying car’ are designs that could get an airworthiness certificate under the current FAA regulations. Airplanes can glide to a safe landing if there’s a problem with power, helicopters can auto-rotate, but the ordinary multi-rotor just drops like a rock if something affects all the power, or tumble in a mass or flesh-eating props if one or a couple motors fail. I don’t want to fly or ride in an aircraft that can’t glide and doesn’t have a pilot to pick the best spot and the FAA won’t let me. Military and Experimental aircraft don’t have to get a Standard Airworthiness Certificate, but any manufactured aircraft does. I believe we’ll see the small cargo drones that can operate between fixed locations rigged for safe operations are certified before anything that can carry passengers. Maybe if stuff is carried 100% safely or nearly, people will be too? Meanwhile, helicopters can’t be operated except from heliports, planes need runways, and flying cars aren’t going to be landing in your neighborhood soon. It takes a pilot’s certificate, an instrument rating, and proficiency to operate in today’s air traffic control system. In a couple years, a drone can do it…

A former company officer donated the Airphibian in 1960 and Robert Fulton III restored it in 1998. Every one of the 100 or so flying cars designed had a fate like this; America was never short of technical ingenuity.
